title: Field Sanitation Practices

requirements.question: Are field sanitation stations maintained with adequate supplies throughout the harvest day?
Are procedures in place for cleaning and sanitizing harvest tools and equipment between uses or fields?
Is there a protocol for managing waste and trash during harvest operations to prevent product contamination?
Are procedures enforced to prevent workers from placing personal items on or near product contact surfaces?
Is there adequate supervision to ensure sanitation practices are followed during harvest operations?

mandatoryStatements: Field sanitation stations must be maintained throughout the harvest day with adequate supplies of soap, water, towels, and sanitizer.
Harvest tools and equipment that contact product must be cleaned and sanitized at appropriate intervals to prevent cross-contamination.
Waste and trash must be managed through designated receptacles and regular removal to prevent attraction of pests and product contamination.
Workers must be prohibited from placing personal items (lunch boxes, water bottles, phones, etc.) on or near product contact surfaces.
Adequate supervision must be present during harvest operations to monitor and enforce compliance with sanitation requirements.
capaInject: Establish a field sanitation monitoring program with designated personnel responsible for checking and restocking supplies hourly or as needed.
Develop tool and equipment sanitation schedules based on risk assessment, with defined frequencies and verification procedures.
Implement a waste management protocol including placement of adequate receptacles, regular emptying schedule, and proper disposal methods.
Create designated areas for personal item storage away from harvest operations with clear signage and worker training.
Define supervisor-to-worker ratios and monitoring responsibilities to ensure adequate oversight of sanitation practices during harvest.
traceabilityInject: Maintain logs of field sanitation station checks including time, supplies checked, deficiencies noted, and restocking actions.
Document tool and equipment cleaning and sanitization activities including date, time, item cleaned, method used, and responsible person.
Keep records of waste removal from harvest areas including frequency, volume, disposal location, and responsible contractor if applicable.
Log any violations of personal item policies including date, worker, description, and corrective action taken.
Track supervisor presence during harvest operations including names, areas covered, hours, and sanitation observations documented.
micro_inject: Emphasize that harvest tools and equipment can transfer pathogens between plants, rows, or fields if not properly cleaned and sanitized.
Ensure adequate sanitation supplies are maintained to prevent situations where workers cannot practice proper hygiene due to supply depletion.
Implement protocols for waste receptacles to be covered and emptied frequently to prevent them from becoming sources of contamination or pest attraction.
Verify that personal items do not create cross-contamination pathways from non-food areas to product contact surfaces during harvest.
Monitor that supervisor presence and engagement are adequate to identify and correct sanitation lapses before product contamination occurs.
